origination.corpname: Episcopal Church. Diocese of Western Michigan.

did.unittitle: Episcopal Church, Diocese of Western Michigan records 1851-2011
did.abstract: Governing body of the Episcopal church in western Michigan, established in 1874; records include bishops' files, diocesan organization and committee files, photographs, scrapbooks, diocesan historian files.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The bulk of the record group was received in four accessions, 1972, 1990, 1994, 1998, and 2012. Periodic additions are expected. (Donor no. 5247)

accessrestrict.p: The records are open for research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is retained by the Diocese of Western Michigan.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., Episcopal Church, Diocese of Western Michigan records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Although the Episcopal Diocese of Western Michigan was not established until 1874, the Episcopal Church first began ministering in this areas as early as the 1820s. In the first decade after the Civil War, many new parishes and mission were established, leading to the establishment of a diocese separate from the Diocese of Michigan in December of 1874.

Elected on the first ballot, Reverend George D. Gillespie was chosen as the first Bishop of the Diocese. Bishop Gillespie began his association with the Diocese of Western Michigan as rector of St. Andrew's in Ann Arbor. He was consecrated as Bishop on the Feast of St. Matthias February 24, 1875 in St. Mark's Church in Grand Rapids. The limitations of advancing age brought about the election of his future replacement, the Rt. Reverend John N. McCormick, in 1906. Bishop Gillespie suffered a stroke in February of 1907 and consequently resigned in the spring of the following year. He died on March 19, 1909.

Bishop McCormick served an eight year rectorate at St. Mark's in Grand Rapids before being elected to serve as Bishop of the Diocese. Bishop McCormick succeeded Bishop Gillespie in 1909 and served a thirty year term. On January 21, 1936 his 30th anniversary of consecration, Bishop McCormick asked the 62nd Annual Convention of the Diocese to elect a new Bishop. Bishop McCormick died three years later on November 26, 1939.

The third Bishop of the Diocese, the Rt. Reverend Lewis B. Whittemore, was born on June 17, 1885. He served as rector of Grace Church, Grand Rapids before his election in 1936. Bishop Whittemore helped found two new congregations, St. Francis in Orangeville and St. Mary's in Cadillac. During his episcopacy, the "Bishop's News Letter" was established, the Women's Auxiliary was refashioned into the Episcopal Churchwomen, and the Bishop Whittemore Foundation was developed. At the 1952 Convention, Bishop Whittemore submitted his resignation and retired on June 16, 1953. He died on December 5, 1965.

At a special convention on March 17, 1953 Rev. Dudley B. McNeil was appointed Bishop Coadjutor. Prior to his election, he served at Sault Ste. Marie. Bishop McNeil helped to start many new congregations in the Diocese, including St. Andrew's in Grand Rapids, St. John's in Fremont, St. Gregory's in Muskegon, and St. James on Beaver Island. In the summer of 1959 Bishop McNeil resigned due to ill health. The details of his subsequent life and death were not readily available in Diocesan records.

Rt. Reverend Charles E. Bennison, the fifth Bishop of the Diocese of Western Michigan, was born on July 23, 1917. He was elected Bishop Coadjutor on November 24, 1959 and consecrated as Bishop on February 24, 1960 85 years after the first Bishop was consecrated. Bishop Bennison began his career in the Diocese of Western Michigan as rector of St. Luke's in Kalamazoo, Michigan. During his episcopacy, Bishop Bennison re-established the deaneries of the diocese, began a companion relationship with the Dioceses of Kimberley and Kuruman, South Africa, formed the Commission on Ministry, Ordained and oversaw discussions on ordained women priests and human sexuality.

Perhaps the most noted accomplishment of Bishop Bennison's career was the Diocesan Center's move from Grand Rapids to Kalamazoo and the subsequent building of the Cathedral Church of Christ the King. In 1964 at the 90th Annual Convention Meeting, Kalamazoo was designated See City. One year later, the Convention voted to embark upon a two million dollar capital funds drive to build the Cathedral and Diocesan Center. Construction began in 1967 and the Cathedral was dedicated two years later.

Bishop Bennison retired in 1984 and was succeeded by Bishop Howard S. Meeks. Bishop Meeks was elected Bishop Coadjutor at the 109th Annual Convention, and was consecrated on October 6, 1984. In January 1988 Bishop Meeks resigned effective February 1st. The Standing Committee and Executive Council took charge of The Diocese and the Rt. Reverend Lyman C. Ogilby accepted the invitation to become an "Episcopal Visitor" during the interim.

At a special convention held on June 3, 1989 Rev. Edward L. Lee was selected as Bishop Coadjutor to fill the position left vacant by Bishop Meeks. He served as rector of St. John's Church, Georgetown Parish in Washington, D.C. before coming to Michigan. He was consecrated on November 26, 1989.

Robert R. Gepert was elected bishop October 19, 2001 consecrated April 27, 2002 and retired in August 2013. During his tenure, the diocese has faced significant financial challenges, and, in 2007 the Cathedral of Christ the King was sold.

scopecontent.p: The records of the Episcopal Diocese of Western Michigan are a rich resource of material, not only for the programs and activities of the Episcopal Church in western Michigan, but also for their documentation of the role of the church in the life of the various communities served by the diocese.

Records from the Episcopal Diocese of Western Michigan first came to the Bentley Historical Library in 1972. Since then, the diocese has made several significant additions to their records. In 1999 the record group was reprocessed with the aim of drawing together like materials. The record group now consists of twenty-two separate series. These are: Bishop's Files, Chancellor, Treasurer, Diocesan Historiographer, Standing Committee Files, Miscellaneous Files, Diocesan Record Books, Publicity Files, Defunct Parish and Mission Churches Files, Diocesan Committee Files, Diocesan Organization Files, Diocesan Financial Records, Visual Materials, Sound Recordings, Scrapbooks, Western Michigan University (WMU) Ministry Files, Women's Organizations, Miscellaneous office and staff files Bulletins of Church Services, Church of Christ the King, Miscellaneous parish materials, and Miscellaneous diocesan materials.

scopecontent.p: The Bishops series consists of six sub-series covering the papers of Bishops George D. Gillespie, Lewis B. Whittemore, Charles E. Bennison, Howard S. Meeks, Edward L. Lee, and Robert R. Gepert.
The George D. Gillespie subseries consists of five record volumes dating from 1875-1908 and documenting this bishop's activities within the diocese.

The Lewis B. Whittemore sub-series is further divided into Parish and Mission Correspondence which is arranged alphabetically by the name of the city where the individual Episcopal parish or mission is located; and Topical Files that include correspondence and information about diocesan activities and property.
The papers of Charles E. Bennison, the third subseries in the Bishop's Files series, includes Correspondence, Topical Files, and Parish and Mission Files.

Onekema, St. John's By the Lake 1964-1989

scopecontent.p: The papers of Howard S. Meeks contain similar records as Bishop Bennison's papers. Files of note include the Commission on Ministry, Ordained, which contains documents regarding the selection process for the ministry. The Executive Council and the Executive Council, National files contain minutes, financial reports, and correspondence about the financial and social issues concerning the diocese and the National Episcopal Church.

The files of Bishops Lee and Gepert have been put into separate alphabetical files. Before researching the papers of Bishops Bennison, Meeks, and Lee, the researcher should note that papers from one bishop May be found in the files of the other. The dates provided after each folder heading should provide information necessary to determine in which episcopate the papers were created.

scopecontent.p: The Bishop Gepert sub-series, arranged alphabetically, in addition to its documentation of the Executive Council and the Diocesan Conventions, also includes extensive material relating to the church's anti-racism initiatives.

did.unittitle: Cathedral Sales Agreement and related material 2007

scopecontent.p: The Chancellor series includes topical files of Charles L. Dibble, Burritt Hamilton, and Niel Weathers. These files are either arranged alphabetically by topic or chronologically if miscellaneous material. The series covers the period from 1925 to 1963.
The Treasurer series contains topical files of diocesan treasurers Harry C. Angell and Norman A. Lilly. Arranged alphabetically, these subseries span the period from 1925-1939.

Another strength of the record group is its documentation of numerous local Episcopal parishes and missions in western Michigan. The files of the Diocesan Historiographer, the officer responsible for collecting historical information on diocesan churches, together with the correspondence files of the other diocesan offices document local parish activities, largely from about 1930 to the 1980s. Included in the collection is the manuscript copy and additional notes for Rev. Franklin Smith's history The Diocese of Western Michigan. This volume provides a thorough history of the diocese to 1948 and should be consulted as background to the archival records. This series also includes files of historiographer Maurice F. Thomas and Betty Sutton. Within the Betty Sutton subseries, in addition to collected material on the individual parishes, there is an extensive set of files with biographical information on the priests of the diocese.

scopecontent.p: The Standing Committee series contains papers that span the period 1936 to 1955. The series is arranged chronologically.
The Miscellaneous Files series contains papers that cover both financial and diocesan matters, as well as contains list of confirmations and clergy members. The series spans the period 1875-1968.

scopecontent.p: The Diocesan Record Books series contains late nineteenth and early twentieth century, books detailing the activities of the individual clergymen in the diocese.

did.unittitle: Journal of the Diocese of Western Michigan 1894-1909

scopecontent.p: The Publicity Files contains papers of Elizabeth Slye, arranged alphabetically, and primarily concerned with the diocesan publications. The series spans the period from 1904-1968 with the majority of the papers from the 1960s.

scopecontent.p: The records of Defunct Parish and Mission Churches provide historical and genealogical information dating back to the 1860s for many western Michigan communities.

scopecontent.p: The Diocesan Committee Files series contains the minutes of the Executive Council, the Executive Committee, the Standing Committee and the Finance Committees from 1874 to 1984. Some of these materials will also be found in the Topical Files of the Bishop's Files series

The Diocesan Organization Files series includes the minutes from meetings of the Akeley Institute Board of Trustees, the Association of the Diocese of Western Michigan and its Board of Trustees, and the Semiannual Missionary Meeting. The records span 1875 to 1984.

did.unittitle: Akeley Institute Board of Trustees, Minutes 1911-1964
Association of the Diocese of Western Michigan, Minutes 1875-1984
Association of the Diocese of Western Michigan Board of Trustees, Minutes 1876-1985

scopecontent.p: The Diocesan Financial Records series consists of four linear feet of volumes of the financial records covering a period from 1874 to 1952. The volumes document various funds managed by the diocese, as well as document the financial history of the diocese.

The Visual Materials series contains photographs of personalities and buildings associated with the diocese, as well as photographs of parish and mission churches. There are also slides and videotapes of church consecration services and of the Cathedral of Christ the King.

did.unittitle: Bishop Bennison, Visit to Kimberley and Kuruman 1962
Portraits of Bishops and with others
The Cathedral of Christ the King undated
The Consecration of Edward Lewis Lee, Jr. undated
A Conversation with Bishop Lee January 1996
The Liturgy for the Ordination and Consecration of Robert R. Gepert as a Bishop in the Church of God and Bishop Coadjutor of the Diocese of Western Michigan April 27, 2002

scopecontent.p: The Sound Recordings series includes cassette tapes of meetings of the annual convention.

did.unittitle: Recordings of annual conventions of the diocese 1995, 1998, 2004

scopecontent.p: The Scrapbook series contains newspaper clippings and other materials relating to the activities of the diocese. The scrapbooks date from 1911 to 1987.

The Western Michigan University (WMU) Ministry Files contains files arranged alphabetically, which cover the time period 1949-1992. The papers relate to the activities and outreach of the diocese to the community of WMU.

scopecontent.p: The Women's Organization Files series consists of one linear foot of records from the Episcopal Churchwomen which cover the period from 1952 to 1997. Papers of note in this series are Annual Meeting Reports, minutes from the Executive Committee, and Treasurer's Reports.

did.unittitle: Women's Auxiliary to the Board of Missions

scopecontent.p: The Miscellaneous office and staff files series contains a miscellanea of files of different church officials and church committees. These include the Diocesan Deployment Office, files relating to the Cathedral Church, and miscellaneous financial materials. Included in this series are files relating to the Cathedral building: planning and fund raising material, the art within the building, publicity, programs of various dedicatory services, and related information.

scopecontent.p: The Bulletins are the weekly order of service for the Cathedral Church of Christ the King. The bulletins date from 1968 to 2003.
The following series comprise most of the 2012 accession: Church of Christ the King, Miscellaneous parish materials, and Miscellaneous diocesan materials.

The Church of Christ the King series consists of administrative and financial documents, vestry and other meeting minutes, parish newsletters (Chimes), photographs (slides), and scrapbooks, as well as other assorted materials including selected sermons by Rev. Cynthia L. Black. Related materials May be found under Miscellaneous office and staff files, Cathedral building and under Visual Materials, Photographs, Cathedral.

Scrapbook of newspaper clippings and photographs related to the construction of the cathedral 1965-1969

scopecontent.p: The Miscellaneous parish materials series contains materials collected from various parishes within the diocese. The materials are arranged by city alphabetically and then by parish name and include photographs as well as programs and other documents.

did.unittitle: St. Michael's Episcopal Church art auction photographs 2004

scopecontent.p: The Miscellaneous diocesan materials series consists of materials related to the diocese as a whole. This includes materials related to events such as the orientation for new clergy as well as items of correspondence sent to many or all parishes in the diocese. Related materials May be found in the Miscellaneous office and staff files series.
